H2-SCR of NO on Pt–MnO x catalysts: Reaction path via NH3 formation Se Min Park a Mi-Young Kim a Eun Seok Kim b Hyun-Sik Han b Gon Seo a ⁎ a School of Applied Chemical Engineering and the Research Institute for Catalysis, Chonnam National University, 77 Yongbong-ro, Buk-gu, Gwangju 500-757, Republic of Korea b Heesung Catalyst Corp., 1251-6 Jungwang-Dong, Shihung, Gyeonggi, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 62 530 1876; fax: +82 62 530 1899. Graphical abstract Research highlights ► Prepared Pt–MnO x catalysts are active in the formation of NH3 from NO x and H2. ► They effectively reduce NO x by using supplied H2 or produced NH3. ► Manganese oxide and platinum show a synergistic effect in H2-SCR of NO x . Pt–MnO x catalysts without any alkali or transition metals were prepared and their performance in the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO by H2 was examined. Their physicochemical properties were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD), extended X-ray adsorption fine structure (EXAFS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The adsorption and removal of NO during H2-SCR were monitored by an in situ FT-IR spectrophotometer. The co-presence of MnO and MnO2 on Pt–MnO x was confirmed by EXAFS and XPS. NO was adsorbed on them as nitrate and nitrite, which were subsequently transformed to NH x species by the introduction of H2. The NH x species adsorbed on the acid sites of manganese oxide were active in the reduction of NO, although a direct reduction by H2 was also possible. The conversion of NO over the Pt(2.0)–MnO x catalyst was maximized to 64% at around 100°C and fell with further increases in temperature. The N2 yield over the Pt(2.0)–MnO x catalyst was 30% at the same condition, indicating that about a half of NO was converted to N2. On the contrary, the Pt(2.0)/SiO2 catalyst exhibited very low N2 yield, 10%, because N2O was highly produced. The reaction between the hydrogen atoms activated on the platinum and the activated NO on the manganese oxide was considered essential for H2-SCR, and NH3 that formed as an intermediate effectively participated to the selective reduction. Keywords Manganese oxide Platinum impregnation H2-SCR NO NH3 formation 1 Introduction Diesel engines have the highest fuel efficiency among internal combustion engines, but their heavy vibration and intense noise have limited their application beyond heavy trucks and buses. Recently, significant improvements in diesel engine performance have lowered their disadvantages and expanded their application to small passenger cars [1]. The expanded applications of diesel engines, however, has caused severe air pollution due to their higher emissions of NO x and particulate matter, which have forced a significant reduction in the permitted exhaust level of NO x from 0.25g/km at Euro IV to 0.08g/km at Euro VI [2]. The reductive removal of NO x contained in the exhaust of diesel engines is not a trivial matter given their operation under excess O2 conditions. The optimization of the diesel engine structure and the introduction of an exhaust gas recirculation system greatly reduce the NO x emissions, but satisfying the strengthened regulations requires after treatment of diesel engine exhaust. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) systems of NO x that use a urea solution as a reductant have been partially introduced in heavy trucks and buses [3–5]. However, urea-SCR systems suffer several disadvantages, including the installation of a huge tank and a complex injection apparatus for the urea solution and the emission of ammonia produced from air that is excessively dosed with urea, known as “ammonia slip”. In contrast to urea, the use of hydrogen as a reductant for SCR does not induce any secondary pollutants. Hydrogen can effectively reduce NO x (H2-SCR), and excessive hydrogen is readily consumed by it reacting with O2 in the diesel engine exhaust [6–13]. A capricious problem concerning H2-SCR is the on-site supply system of hydrogen for the vehicles. A compact hydrogen generator supplied with additional fuels or hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide contained in the exhaust can enhance the feasibility of H2-SCR as an effective route to NO x removal. However, the presence of excess O2 is a major obstacle as it induces the combustion of hydrogen to H2O. Noble metal catalysts are active in H2-SCR in the absence of O2, but the presence of O2 significantly lowers the selective reduction of NO x to N2 by producing N2O and consuming H2 in the formation of H2O [6,9]. As a result, the improvement of N2 selectivity over noble metal catalysts has been studied by varying the loading amount of noble metal and by combining transition metal oxides [6–8]: the noble metal supplies activated hydrogen atoms and the mixed oxide activates NO x which can be easily reduced by hydrogen atoms to N2. Pt/TiO2–ZrO2 and Pt/MgO–CeO2 are typical catalysts exhibiting high activities in H2-SCR, even in the presence of excessive O2 [6,7]. However, their concerted selective reduction mechanism exhibits high sensitivity for N2 selectivity with varying reaction conditions, such as temperature and H2 concentration. The removal of NO x through the formation of NH3 from NO x and H2 and the subsequent removal of NO x by reacting it with produced NH3 is considered a promising alternative for the direct removal of NO x by it reacting with H2. If NH3 is successfully formed through the reaction between NO x and H2, the further removal of NO x by NH3 is made easier because NH3-SCR is a well-established technology used conventionally at many stationary NO x sources [14]. The combination of ammonia formation and NH3-SCR catalysts even in the presence of O2 may effectively remove NO x from diesel engine exhaust. The formation of NH3 through the reaction between NO and H2 is thermodynamically feasible because of the simultaneous production of thermodynamically stable H2O. However, the presence of O2 in the reactant significantly lowers the selectivity for NH3 due to competition with the formation of H2O by reacting H2 with O2. Actually, the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits a high activity in the formation of NH3 from NO and H2 when O2 is absent, but the presence of 3% O2 severely limits the formation of NH3 [9]. The physical mixture of Pt/ZrO2 and HZSM-5 zeolite was reported to be active and selective in the H2-SCR of NO even in the presence of O2: NH3 was formed on Pt/ZrO2 and the selective reduction of NO by NH3 occurred on HZSM-5 [10]. A mixed oxide of iron and manganese supported on titania is a highly active and selective catalyst for NH3-SCR [15]. Manganese oxide works as an active phase and the co-existence of iron oxide improves its dispersion and selectivity for N2 formation. Since manganese oxide itself and a mixed oxide of manganese and cerium are also highly active in NH3-SCR, manganese oxide is considered as a potential material for H2-SCR through NH3. Manganese oxides with higher oxidation states were more active in NH3-SCR and the oxygen vacancies generated during the reduction by NH3 worked as adsorption sites for NO x [16]. However, the co-presence of alkali ions and transition metals with manganese oxides makes it difficult to elucidate the catalytic role of the manganese oxide itself. In this study, we prepare a manganese oxide without any alkali or transition metal to investigate the catalytic role of manganese oxide in the H2-SCR of NO. Different loading levels of platinum were impregnated on the catalyst to confirm the effect of hydrogen activation on the extent of H2-SCR. An in situ IR study provides information on the adsorption of NO x on the Pt–MnO x catalysts, on the formation of NH3 on the catalysts even in the presence of excess O2 in the feed, and on the removal of NO x by activated hydrogen atoms. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts Manganese oxide was precipitated from a solution of manganese nitrate (98%, Kanto) by adding ammonium carbonate (98%, Kanto) solution until a pH of 6.3 was achieved. The filtrate was washed with deionized H2O and dried at 85°C. The manganese oxide (MnO x ) was obtained by calcining at 500°C for 4h followed by reducing at 400°C in a reduction gas (Hankook Special Gases) flow composed of a 1:1 molar ratio of nitrogen to hydrogen. Platinum was impregnated on the Mn oxide by an incipient wetness method. The loading amounts of platinum in the metallic state were controlled at 1.0 and 2.0 wt% by adding a given amount of chloroplatinic acid hydrate (99.9%, Aldrich) solution. After drying at 100°C, the Pt–MnO x catalysts were reduced at 400°C in the reduction gas flow. The Pt catalysts supported on manganese oxide were denoted by Pt–MnO x , not by Pt/MnO x , because manganese oxide worked as an active phase as well as a support in these catalysts. The amount of platinum loaded on the catalysts was denoted by writing the loading amounts in parentheses after Pt; for example, Pt(1.0)–MnO x and Pt(2.0)–MnO x . The Pt(2.0)/SiO2 catalyst supported on a precipitated silica (Tokusil 255, Oriental Silicas Corporation) with a platinum loading of 2.0 wt% was prepared as a reference catalyst by the same method as used in the preparation of the Pt–MnO x catalysts. The silica was selected to have only a metallic platinum state after reduction at 400°C, which was comparable to that on the Pt–MnO x catalysts. 2.2 Characterization of the prepared MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts The chemical compositions of the oxide and catalysts were determined by using an inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, Perkin–Elmer Optima 4300 DV). The sample was dissolved at 100°C for 12h in a 6-ml mixture of hydrogen fluoride (70%, Aldrich) and nitric acid (99.9%, Aldrich) in a Teflon vessel equipped with an air-tight cover. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (HR-XRD, Rigaku, Ultima III) operated at 40kV and 40mA using a Cu Kα X-ray filtered with a nickel filter. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms were obtained using an automated adsorption measuring apparatus (MiraeSI, nanoPorosity-XG). A 0.1g sample was evacuated at 250°C for 2h prior to nitrogen (99.999%, Hankook Special Gases) exposure at liquid nitrogen temperature. The surface areas were calculated from the nitrogen adsorption isotherms using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra of the manganese atoms of the oxide and catalysts were recorded at the 3C1 beamline of the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory. The X-rays were monochromated by a double crystal monochromator composed of Si(111) and Si(311) crystals. The X-ray absorption was measured in a transmission mode around the Mn K-edge (6539eV) by detuning to the range of 70–80% to eliminate higher harmonics. The sample was reduced at 400°C in a reduction gas (Hankook Special Gases) flow of a 1:1 molar ratio of nitrogen to hydrogen in an in situ EXAFS cell. The EXAFS spectra were recorded after exchanging the reduction gas flow for a 100ml/min flow of N2 gas (99.995%, Hankook Special Gases) and cooling to room temperature. The radial distribution of the manganese atoms was obtained from the fourier-transformed (FT) absorption spectra and analyzed using XFIT software based on the FEFF8.1 theoretical model. An X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, VG MultiLab 2000) was used in the surface examination of the oxide and catalysts. The binding energy of each element was calibrated with the C1s peak (285.0eV). The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were obtained using a chemisorption measurement apparatus (BEL-CAT, BEL Japan). A 0.05g sample of catalyst was charged in a quartz tube with a 6mm O.D. and pretreated in a 100ml/min flow of Ar gas (99.995%, Hankook Special Gases) at 400°C for 1h. After cooling to 50°C, the catalyst was subsequently heated from 50°C to 800°C at 5°C/min in a 100ml/min flow of H2-mixed gas (H2 5%/Ar balance, Hankook Special Gases). 2.3 IR study on the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts CO adsorption on the Pt–MnO x catalysts was monitored using an FT-IR spectrophotometer (BIO-RAD, 175C) at 50°C. A catalyst wafer (13mg) was charged in an in situ IR cell (Graseby Specac) and evacuated at 500°C for 1h. After cooling to 50°C, the evacuated catalyst was exposed to CO gas at 30Torr (99.95%, Hankook Special Gases). After evacuating the catalyst wafer for 10min, the IR spectra of the CO adsorbed on it were recorded by accumulating 16 scans in the range of 4000–700cm−1 with a resolution of 4cm−1 to lower the signal-to-noise ratio. The adsorption of NO and its reduction by H2 on the Pt–MnO x catalysts were also monitored by the FT-IR spectrophotometer. A catalyst wafer (13mg) was pretreated with a 100ml/min flow of He gas (99.995%, Hankook Special Gases) at 500°C for 1h, and then exposed to a 100ml/min flow of NO-mixed gas (NO 480ppmv/O2 5%/N2 balance) for 30min. The flow was changed to a 100ml/min flow of H2-mixed gas (H2 0.8%/He balance) at various temperatures to observe the removal of NO x and the formation of NH3. In investigating the adsorption of NH3 and the NH3-SCR reaction of NO on the Pt–MnO x catalysts, the catalyst wafer pretreated in a 100ml/min flow of He gas at 500°C for 1h was exposed to a NH3 gas (99.995%, Hankook Special Gases) pulse of 2ml. A 100ml/min flow of NO-mixed gas (NO 480ppmv/O2 5%/H2 balance) was fed into the reactor to examine the reduction of NO by adsorbed NH3. 2.4 H2-SCR reaction of NO over Pt–MnO x catalysts NO was subjected to catalytic reduction by H2 over the Pt–MnO x and Pt(2.0)/SiO2 catalysts in an atmospheric flow reactor system. A 0.1g sample of catalyst was charged in a quartz tube with a 10mm O.D. and activated in a 100ml/min flow of He gas at 500°C for 1h. After cooling to 50°C, a 100ml/min flow of NO/O2-mixed gas (NO 480ppmv/O2 5vol%/He balance) was fed to establish an adsorption equilibrium. Subsequently, H2 gas was continuously injected into the NO/O2-mixed gas to maintain H2 concentrations of 0.4, 0.8, and 1.0%, depending on the test. The reduced amount of NO and the consumed amount of H2 were measured using a combined detection system comprised of a mass spectrometer (Balzers, QMS200), a nondispersive infrared (NDIR) gas analyzer (Siemens, ULTRAMAT 6), and a NO x analyzer (ECO Physic, CLD 844 CMH r). The concentrations of NO (m/e =30), NO2 (m/e =46), N2O (m/e =44), N2 (m/e =28), H2O (m/e =18), and NH3 (m/e =15, 16 and 17) in the product gas stream were measured from their mass signals. The fragmentation patterns of these products at the lowest ionization potential obtained from their standard gases were utilized in the calculation of their concentrations. The concentrations of NO and N2O were simultaneously confirmed by the NDIR gas analyzer and that of NO2 by the NO x analyzer. The conversion of NO (X NO) was defined as the fraction of NO converted to N-containing species, such as N2, N2O, NH3, and NO2. The yield of a N-containing species was calculated as the percentage of the NO consumed for the production of the material per the NO fed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical state of the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts The bulk and surface compositions of the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The bulk content of manganese in the MnO x at 74.1 wt% was slightly higher than that calculated from the pure MnO, which indicated a co-existence of manganese atoms with higher oxidation states, such as Mn3+ and Mn4+. The impregnation of platinum on the MnO x did not induce any appreciable change in the manganese content. The surface concentrations of manganese on the Pt–MnO x catalysts determined from their XPS spectra were denoted by atom% and they were slightly higher than that on the MnO x : the surface content of manganese on Pt(1.0)–MnO x was 41.7 atom%, while that on MnO x was 35.1 atom%. The removal of oxygen and carbon from the catalyst surface by the H2 atoms activated on the platinum during the reduction treatment increased their surface contents of manganese. Pt(2.0)/SiO2 exhibited a lower surface concentration of platinum than did Pt(2.0)–MnO x , although the bulk platinum contents were the same on both catalysts. The dispersion of platinum particles in the pores of the silica was responsible for its low surface concentration. The BET surface areas of the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts were both around 30m2/g, while that of Pt(2.0)/SiO2 was high at 170m2/g because of the high surface area of the silica. The crystalline structure of MnO x is strongly dependent upon the treatment. The calcined MnO x exhibited definite diffraction peaks of Mn2O3 (PDF#41-1442) at 2θ =23.0°, 38.2°, and 55.2°, as shown in Fig. S1. However, the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalyst reduced in the reduction flow at 400°C revealed diffraction peaks of MnO (PDF#07-0230) at 2θ =35.0°, 40.6°, and 58.7°, indicating the reduction of Mn2O3 to MnO, regardless of platinum impregnation. Fig. 1 shows the FT radial distributions of manganese atoms obtained from the EXAFS spectra of the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts. Although the lengths of atomic pairs in the radial distributions were generally shorter by 0.2–0.5Å compared to the real lengths because of the phase difference, the real lengths were mentioned here [17]. The peaks observed at 2.2 and 3.1Å were attributed to Mn–O and Mn–Mn atomic pairs of the MnO phase, respectively [18]. However, the peak at 1.9Å was caused by the Mn–O atomic pair of the Mn2O3 phase [19]. Since the peak relative to the Mn–Mn atomic pair of the latter had a similar length to that of the former, they could not be resolved. The presence of two Mn–O atomic pairs with different lengths indicated the co-existence of MnO and Mn2O3 phases in the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts. The dispersion of platinum on the Pt(2.0)–MnO x and Pt(2.0)/SiO2 catalysts differed slightly, as shown in Fig. S2. The TEM photo of the former exhibited highly dispersed platinum particles of less than 1nm, while relatively large platinum particles of 1–5nm were observed on the latter. The oxidation states of the manganese and platinum atoms dispersed on the surface of the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts were deduced from their XPS spectra (Fig. 2 ). The Mn 2p3/2 peak of 641.5eV indicated the presence of the Mn2O3 phase on their surfaces and the Pt 4f7/2 peak of 71.7eV corresponded to the metallic state of platinum [20–22]. Although the EXAFS results indicated the co-presence of the MnO and Mn2O3 phases in the bulk of MnO x and Pt–MnO x , the Mn2O3 phase was predominant on their surfaces. The IR spectra of carbon monoxide adsorbed on the Pt–MnO x and Pt(2.0)/SiO2 catalysts also confirmed the presence of metallic platinum. The absorption bands of CO at 2048cm−1, which were attributed to its adsorption on the platinum metal, were observed on the Pt–MnO x catalysts, as shown in Fig. S3 [23]. The larger band of CO on Pt(2.0)/SiO2 revealed a higher platinum dispersion than that on Pt(2.0)–MnO x , even though the Pt 4f XPS peaks of the former were smaller than those of the latter. Most of the platinum particles dispersed on the former were located in its pores, which were screened from XPS examination. The impregnation of platinum on the MnO x significantly lowered its reduction temperature, as shown in Fig. 3 . The reduction of the MnO x in a H2 flow caused two reduction peaks with maxima at 501 and 590°C, while the temperatures at the maxima of the reduction profile obtained from the Pt(2.0)–MnO x catalyst were 265, 305, and 350°C. The TPR profile from Pt(2.0)/SiO2 did not show any appreciable peaks because the platinum on it had already been converted to a metallic state in the reduction treatment of its preparation and the content of platinum was very small compared to that of manganese. Therefore, the reduction peaks observed from the TPR profile of the Pt(2.0)–MnO x catalyst were responsible for the reduction of the manganese species. The amount of H2 consumed in the reduction of the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts was 3.71 and 3.70mmol/g, respectively, indicating that about half of the manganese atoms were reduced from Mn3+ to Mn2+ during the TPR experiment. The consecutive change in the oxidation state of the manganese atoms in the order of Mn2O3 →Mn3O4 →MnO caused these multiple TPR peaks [24,25]. However, the lower temperatures for the reduction peaks of the Pt(2.0)–MnO x catalyst compared to those of the MnO x indicated that the manganese species with higher oxidation states of the former were easily reduced by H2 atoms activated on the surface of the platinum. The XRD patterns of the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts clearly exhibited the presence of the MnO crystalline phase, while their compositions and EXAFS spectra suggested a partial co-existence of the Mn2O3 phase. The XPS peaks of the manganese atoms also revealed the presence of the Mn2O3 phase on the surface. The manganese atoms with higher oxidation states may have been concentrated on the surface due to the relatively high surface oxygen concentration, but the high dispersion of the amorphous Mn2O3 phase into the MnO phase is also possible. Since platinum impregnated on the MnO x and silica had already been reduced to the metallic state in the reduction treatment of the preparation, the manganese species with higher oxidation states, especially Mn3+, were reduced to Mn2+ in the TPR experiment. The considerable lowering of the reduction temperatures of the Pt–MnO x catalysts clearly revealed the facile reduction of manganese atoms with higher oxidation states by supplying hydrogen atoms activated on platinum. 3.2 Reductive removal of NO by H2 over Pt–MnO x catalysts The adsorption of NO and reductive removal by H2 were monitored by using an in situ IR spectrophotometer. Fig. 4 shows the IR spectra of various species adsorbed on Pt(2.0)–MnO x during the H2-SCR of NO. The exposure of a NO/O2-mixed gas flow caused the appearance of absorption bands at 1790, 1610, and 1325cm−1. The band at 1790cm−1 was attributed to nitrosyl and the band at 1610cm−1 was attributed to bidentate nitrate adsorbed on MnO x [26,27]. The band at 1325cm−1 was assigned to nitrite species bound on MnO x through an oxygen atom [27]. The appearance of these bands indicated that NO was adsorbed on the surface of MnO x directly and through oxygen atoms by forming nitrite species. NO was also oxidized to nitrate on the platinum. The switch of the NO/O2 gas to H2 gas induced definite changes in the IR spectra: strong bands appeared at 1417 and 1190cm−1 with the introduction of H2 at 50°C, while the bands at 1790 and 1325cm−1 disappeared (Fig. 4A). A strong new band was observed at 1637cm−1 after the gas flow switch, but the band slowly decreased over time. The H2 introduction also induced a weak band at 1510cm−1. The bands at 1417 and 1190cm−1 that appeared with the H2 introduction were attributed to NH3 adsorbed on Brönsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively [9,28,29]. The H2O adsorbed on the catalyst caused the band at 1637cm−1, and the amide (NH x ) species caused the band at 1510cm−1 [28,29]. Therefore, the changes in the IR spectra confirmed the progress of the reaction between adsorbed NO x species and H2 over Pt(2.0)–MnO x based on the production of NH3, NH x , and H2O. Wavenumber (cm−1) Chemical species Reference 1798–1760 Nitrosyl on metal oxide [26] 1637 Adsorbed H2O [28] 1610 Bidentate nitrate [27] 1510 Amide [28] 1460 Monodentate nitrate [27] 1417 Adsorbed NH4 + on Brönsted acid site [9,28,29] 1325 Chelating nitrite [27] 1190 Coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid site [9,28,29] The rapid reaction between adsorbed NO x species and H2 at 100°C caused further changes in the IR spectra (Fig. 4B). The clear evidence of the bands attributed to NH3 adsorbed on Brönsted and Lewis acid sites demonstrated the formation of NH3 on Pt(2.0)–MnO x through the reaction between the adsorbed NO x species and H2. The formation of H2O in the reaction between NO x and H2 or between O2 and H2 induced the H2O band. But the higher temperature forced the desorption of H2O, which decreased the H2O band at 1637cm−1. The gradual increase in the band at 1190cm−1 accompanied by the decrease in the band at 1325cm−1 indicated the slow conversion of nitrite species to NH3 and its subsequent adsorption on Lewis acid sites. The formation of NH3 in the presence of O2 by the reaction between NO x and H2 over the Pt–MnO x catalysts was definitely confirmed by the appearance of NH3 bands when the catalysts were exposed to a mixed NO/O2/H2 gas. Fig. 5 shows the IR spectra recorded during the reaction among NO, O2, and H2 over Pt(2.0)–MnO x while the temperature was increasing. The band at 1610cm−1 attributed to adsorbed bidentate nitrate was very high at 50°C, but it decreased as the temperature increased. The bands at 1417 and 1190cm−1 attributed to NH3 adsorbed on acid sites increased with temperature. The band at 1190cm−1 peaked at around 80–100°C, and then decreased as the temperature increased. The absence of the band at 1325cm−1 due to the nitrite species reflected their high activity with H2, while the persistent band at 1780cm−1 represented the strong adsorption of NO on the catalyst surface. The formation of NH3 through the reaction between NO x and H2 over Pt(2.0)–MnO x was definite even in the presence of O2. NO was also oxidized to nitrate. However, the reactions that occurred over Pt(2.0)–MnO x at temperatures above 200°C could not be identified because the adsorption of NO, NH3, and H2O became too small at these elevated temperatures. The reduction of NO by adsorbed NH3 on the Pt(2.0)–MnO x catalyst was also investigated. Fig. 6A shows the IR spectra recorded for the reaction of adsorbed NH3 with NO at different temperatures. The bands attributed to NH3 adsorbed on acid sites were intense at 50°C but slowly decreased with the introduction of the NO-mixed gas flow. The band attributed to NH3 adsorbed on Brönsted acid sites was small at 100°C, whereas the band attribute to NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites remained high. At elevated temperatures, the bands relative to NH3 adsorbed on acid sites became small with the introduction of NO. Fig. 6B shows the decreasing curves of the integrated band areas at 1190cm−1 with time at various temperatures. The rapid decreases of the band at elevated temperatures indicated the rapid removal of NH3 by NO over Pt(2.0)–MnO x . The adsorption of NO and its subsequent reaction with H2 over Pt(2.0)/SiO2 clearly differed from those over Pt(2.0)–MnO x , as shown in Fig. S4. The exposure to the flow of NO/O2 gas caused the appearance of the band at 1620cm−1, which was attributed to bidentate nitrate produced by the oxidation of NO by O2. Very small bands attributed to the adsorbed monodentate nitrate and nitrite at 1460 and 1340cm−1, respectively, were also observed [27]. The introduction of H2 caused the appearance of the band at 1630cm−1 relative to H2O and was accompanied by slight decreases in the bands of the adsorbed nitrate and nitrite. The appearance of the intense H2O band reflected the rapid formation of H2O via the reaction between H2 and O2 or between NOads and Hads. However, the formation of NH3 on Pt(2.0)/SiO2 could not be confirmed because NH3 was not adsorbed on Pt and SiO2 under this condition. The IR spectra of the species adsorbed on Pt(2.0)–MnO x formed in the subsequent adsorption of NO and H2 are shown in Fig. 7 . The catalyst was pretreated in a H2 flow at 400°C for 1h prior to exposure to NO at 100°C. The exposure to NO caused the appearance of bands attributed to nitrosyl and bidentate nitrate adsorbed on the MnO x and Pt surface at 1780 and 1610cm−1, respectively [26,27]. The replacement of the NO gas flow by H2 induced the appearance of the band at 1190cm−1 accompanied by the disappearance of the band at 1780cm−1, which indicated the formation of NH3 by the reaction of adsorbed NO with H2. The repeated operation also exhibited similar IR spectra, which confirmed the feasibility of Pt–MnO x for the H2-SCR of NO. On the other hand, the band at 1610cm−1 attributed to bidentate nitrate on the Pt surface remained during repeated switching of NO gas with H2. The slow removal of NO by adsorbed NH3 at 100°C caused a partial retention of the band at 1190cm−1 after the H2 treatment. On the contrary, the MnO x and Pt(2.0)/SiO2 catalyst results did not show any absorption bands relative to NO or to the species formed with the subsequent introduction of H2, even though they were pretreated with H2 under the same conditions as those for Pt(2.0)–MnO x . This indicated that the co-presence of platinum and manganese oxide are essential for the formation of NH3 through the reaction between NO and H2. Most of the manganese atoms in the MnO x and Pt–MnO x catalysts were divalent (Mn2+), which was their lowest oxidation state, and they were not active in the adsorption of NO. However, some of the manganese atoms had higher oxidation states, especially on the surface. The presence of platinum in the Pt–MnO x catalysts caused the reduction of the manganese atoms with higher oxidation states by the removal of surface oxygen atoms at lower temperatures, as shown in the TPR profiles (Fig. 3). The oxygen vacancies formed in the reduction acted as adsorption sites for NO similar to the adsorption of NO on anion vacant sites on SrFeO3−x and CeO2 [8]. The MnO x did not exhibit any activity in the H2-SCR of NO performed at lower temperatures, but the Pt–MnO x catalysts, which can activate NO through the adsorption of oxygen vacancies formed by hydrogen atoms activated on platinum, were active in the H2-SCR of NO. 3.3 Catalytic performance of the Pt–MnO x catalysts The performance of platinum catalysts in the H2-SCR of NO varies with their supports. Although silica did not induce any appreciable influence on the catalytic performance of platinum, zirconia and ceria caused significant changes [30]. Since manganese oxide is a transition metal oxide which alters its oxidation state according to reaction atmosphere, the interaction between platinum and manganese oxide causes a considerable change in the chemical state of platinum. Furthermore, the co-existence of platinum and manganese oxide leads to a new bifunctional catalytic system. Fig. 8 shows the profiles of NO conversion and yields of N-containing species in the product gas stream in H2-SCR over Pt(2.0)/SiO2 as a function of reaction temperature. NO conversion was maintained at a very high level, about 100%, in this temperature range when O2 was absent in the feed. However, the yields of N-containing species varied largely with reaction temperature. Although the change in product composition can be represented by the selectivities for products, their yields rather than selectivities were used in this paper because a yield denoted the extent of the reaction path towards the production of a given product. At 50°C, the yield of N2O was high at 50%, and those of N2 and NH3 were low at 20%. The increase in reaction temperature increased the yield of NH3, while those of N2 and NH3 decreased. Most of NO was converted to NH3 at 200°C on Pt(2.0)/SiO2 in the absence of excess O2 in the feed. The presence of O2 in the feed in the H2-SCR of NO over Pt(2.0)/SiO2 lowered the NO conversion to 80% at 50°C. Most of the N-containing species in the product gas stream were N2O and the formation of NH3 was not detected. The increase in reaction temperature gradually lowered both the conversion of NO and the yield of N2O. The yield of N2 increased to about 10% at elevated temperatures and the formation of NO2 was observed at 200°C. Since SiO2 is intrinsically inert, the H2-SCR of NO in the absence of excess O2 in the feed over Pt(2.0)/SiO2 proceeds among the molecularly or dissociatively adsorbed NO and the activated hydrogen atoms adsorbed on the platinum metal. The amount of hydrogen exceeded the stoichiometrically required amount for NO reduction by 8 times, and thereby most of the dissociated oxygen atoms from NO reacted with activated hydrogen atoms, resulting in an oxygen deficient surface. Therefore, Nads, NOads, and Hads that remained on the platinum metal surface reacted and produced N2, N2O, and NH3 following the reactions written below: (1) Nads +Nads →N2 (2) Nads +NOads →N2O (3) Nads +3Hads →NH3 The increase in reaction temperature lowered the preference for the molecular adsorption of NO and facilitated the formation of NH3 through the reaction of Nads with Hads that was enriched on platinum. The presence of excess O2 in the feed induced a competition between the adsorptions of NO and O2, resulting in a low NO conversion in H2-SCR over Pt(2.0)/SiO2. The excess O2 consumed activated hydrogen atoms on the platinum by producing H2O, and the formation of NH3 was considerably suppressed. Therefore, the main product of N-containing species at 50°C was N2O produced through the reaction between Nads and NOads presented on the platinum surface. The increase in reaction temperature gradually reduced NO conversion due to the reduction of NO adsorption. The increase in the surface mobility of Nads caused a small degree of N2 formation at elevated temperatures, and the reaction between activated oxygen atoms and NO occurred at 200°C and produced NO2. The H2-SCR of NO over Pt(2.0)–MnO x was considerably different from that over Pt(2.0)/SiO2, as shown in Fig. 9 . NO conversion was low at 40% at 50°C even in the absence of excess O2 in the feed. The increase in reaction temperature concurrently increased NO conversion and the yields of N2 and NH3, accompanying the decrease in the yield of N2O. The yield of NH3 steadily increased with reaction temperature, but that of N2 exhibited a maximum at 125°C and decreased for further temperature increases. The yields of N2 and N2O were very low at 200°C, and thereby most of the NO was converted to NH3. The presence of O2 in the feed also caused significant changes in the NO conversion and the yields of N-containing species. The NO conversion at 50°C was low at 40%, but N2O and N2 were simultaneously formed. NH3 was not detected in the product gas stream at this temperature. NO conversion increased as the reaction temperature increased to 100–125°C, and this was accompanied with increases in the yields of N2O and N2. Further increase in reaction temperature induced concurrent decreases in the conversion of NO and the yields of N2O and N2. However, the yield of N2 in the H2-SCR of NO was relatively high over Pt(2.0)–MnO x compared to Pt(2.0)/SiO2 even in the presence of excess O2. The small surface area of platinum was responsible for the low NO conversion over Pt(2.0)–MnO x at low temperatures, even in the absence of O2. The consumption of Oads that dissociated from NO by Hads on platinum facilitated the formation of N2O, NH3, and N2. The increase in reaction temperature enhanced the formation of NH3 along with reduction of the yield of N2O. The stored NH3 on manganese oxide reduced NO and produced N2. (4) NH3,ads →NH3−x,ads + xHads (5) NOads +NH3−x →N2 +H2O Further increases in reaction temperature enhanced the desorption of NH3, resulting in a high yield of NH3 and a low yield of N2. The co-feeding of excess O2 with NO eliminated the detection of NH3 in the product gas stream, but N2 formed even at 50°C. The presence of O2 with NO on Pt(2.0)–MnO x caused the appearance of nitrate species as well as NH3, as shown in Fig. 4. The reaction between nitrate and NH3 resulted in the formation of N2 at low temperatures. (6) NO− 3,ads +NH x,ads →N2 +H2O The suggested reduction reaction of NOads by NH x,ads also provided a plausible explanation for similar trends in NO conversion and the yields of N2O and N2 depending on the reaction temperature [30]. (7) NOads +NH x,ads →N2 +H x O (8) NOads +NH x,ads →N2O+H x,ads NO conversion and the yields of N2O and N2 exhibited their maxima around 100–125°C, at which the storage amount of NH3 achieved a maximum (Fig. 5) because the absorption bands attributed to NH3 decreased with further temperature increases. The catalytic performances of Pt(2.0)/SiO2 and Pt(2.0)–MnO x in the H2-SCR of NO were definitely different. There were several causes inducing such a difference: the interaction between platinum and its support or the dispersion and chemical state of platinum on the supports. Although platinum is a typical noble metal that is affected by the interaction between it and its support [30], Pt(2.0)/SiO2 and Pt(2.0)–MnO x showed the IR absorption bands that were attributed to adsorbed carbon monoxide at the same wavenumber, excluding the possibility for a significant change in the chemical state of platinum. The participation of manganese oxide in the H2-SCR of NO as an active phase might be more reasonable for explaining the difference in the catalytic performances. The storage of NH3 on manganese oxide (Fig. 4) and the participation of NO adsorbed on manganese oxide in the formation of NH3 (Fig. 7) contributed to the selective reduction of NO on Pt(2.0)–MnO x . The amount of H2 that was fed also influenced the H2-SCR of NO on the Pt–MnO x catalysts. Fig. 10 shows the variation of NO conversion and N2 yield with reaction temperature in the H2-SCR of NO over Pt(2.0)–MnO x at different H2 concentrations. NO conversion was definitely enhanced as the H2 concentration increased from 0.4% to 0.8%, while the further increase to 1.0% did not induce any significant change in NO conversion. The dependence of the N2 yield on the H2 concentration was similar to that of NO conversion. The H2 concentration of 0.4% was 8 times of the stoichiometric amount required for the reduction of NO to N2. If all of the NO was oxidized to NO2 by reaction with the co-presented O2, the surplus ratio was reduced to 4. The fact that the increase in H2 concentration was effective in increasing the NO conversion revealed the importance of the H2 supply to the reduction of NO. However, the further increase in the H2 concentration did not increase the yield of N2. The similar changes of NO conversion and N2 yield with temperature, regardless of H2 concentration, indicated a negligible effect of H2 concentration on the reaction path. The activation of H2 is very important, but the selective reduction of NO to N2 does not mainly occur on the platinum surface [30]. The migration of activated hydrogen atoms to the MnO x and the reaction with adsorbed species on it caused the selective reduction of NO [31,32]. Pt–MnO x catalysts with two active species, platinum metal and manganese oxide, were active in the H2-SCR of NO. Since the adsorption bands of NH3 were high in the flow of the NO/H2/O2 feed gas and the conversion NO over them was also high at around 100–125°C, the formation of NH3 was very important in the H2-SCR. The formation of NH x , including NH3, and its storage on the Pt–MnO x catalysts facilitated the SCR of NO even at low temperatures. The hydrogen atoms that were activated over the platinum migrated to the manganese oxide and reduced the NO activated on the manganese oxide, producing NH3, but the detailed reaction steps that occurred at each site require more systematic investigation. 4 Conclusions MnO x without any alkali or transition metals and the Pt(2.0)/SiO2 catalyst prepared by the impregnation of platinum on inert silica were inactive in the H2-SCR of NO at low temperatures. However, the Pt–MnO x catalysts prepared by impregnating platinum on MnO x exhibited a considerable activity and N2 yield. The formation of NH3 through the reaction between NO and H2 over these catalysts was confirmed by an IR study. Reaction between molecularly and dissociatively adsorbed NO x species and hydrogen atoms adsorbed on the catalysts produced NH3 and resulted in NH3 being stored on MnO x . A further NH3-SCR of NO also occurred on the catalysts, even at low temperatures, although a direct reduction of NO x by H2 was possible. The increase in temperature above 100–125°C reduced the NO conversion due to the reduction of the amount of adsorbed NO and the reduction of the formation of NH x species. The presence of both platinum metal and manganese oxide was essential for the removal of NO by H2-SCR via NH3 formation. coredata.dc:description: Pt–MnO x catalysts without any alkali or transition metals were prepared and their performance in the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO by H2 was examined. Their physicochemical properties were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD), extended X-ray adsorption fine structure (EXAFS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The adsorption and removal of NO during H2-SCR were monitored by an in situ FT-IR spectrophotometer. The co-presence of MnO and MnO2 on Pt–MnO x was confirmed by EXAFS and XPS. NO was adsorbed on them as nitrate and nitrite, which were subsequently transformed to NH x species by the introduction of H2. The NH x species adsorbed on the acid sites of manganese oxide were active in the reduction of NO, although a direct reduction by H2 was also possible. The conversion of NO over the Pt(2.0)–MnO x catalyst was maximized to 64% at around 100°C and fell with further increases in temperature. The N2 yield over the Pt(2.0)–MnO x catalyst was 30% at the same condition, indicating that about a half of NO was converted to N2. On the contrary, the Pt(2.0)/SiO2 catalyst exhibited very low N2 yield, 10%, because N2O was highly produced. The reaction between the hydrogen atoms activated on the platinum and the activated NO on the manganese oxide was considered essential for H2-SCR, and NH3 that formed as an intermediate effectively participated to the selective reduction.
coredata.dc:title: H2-SCR of NO on Pt–MnO x catalysts: Reaction path via NH3 formation
